section.title: Setting Priorities
section.para: A module can override the definitions of an option in other modules by setting an override priority. All option definitions that do not have the lowest priority value are discarded. By default, option definitions have priority 100 and option defaults have priority 1500. You can specify an explicit priority by using mkOverride, e.g.
This definition causes all other definitions with priorities above 10 to be discarded. The function mkForce is equal to mkOverride 50, and mkDefault is equal to mkOverride 1000.

section.title: Ordering Definitions
section.para: It is also possible to influence the order in which the definitions for an option are merged by setting an order priority with mkOrder. The default order priority is 1000. The functions mkBefore and mkAfter are equal to mkOrder 500 and mkOrder 1500, respectively. As an example,
This definition ensures that myFirmware comes before other unordered definitions in the final list value of hardware.firmware.
Note that this is different from override priorities: setting an order does not affect whether the definition is included or not.
